did.unittitle: Cass Gilbert papers and architectural drawings
did.abstract: The Cass Gilbert Collection contains the professional and personal papers of the architect Cass Gilbert. This includes information on his architectural projects, professional affliations, and personal business. This finding aid does not include information on his architectural drawings.
did.langmaterial: The documents in the collection are written in English.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Cass Gilbert Jr. and Emily Gilbert, 1956 and 1957.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to thirty exposures of stable, unbound material per day. See guidelines in Print Room for details.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as the Cass Gilbert Collection, PR 021, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, The New-York Historical Society.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Cass Gilbert was born on November 24, 1859 in Zanesville, Ohio to Samuel Augustus Gilbert and Elizabeth Fulton Wheeler Gilbert. The family moved to St. Paul Minnesota in 1868, and in 1878 Gilbert went to study architecture at Massachusetts Institute of Technology. After traveling and studying in Europe, he joined the New York office of McKim, Mead & White in 1880. In 1882, he was sent to St. Paul to open a branch office for McKim, Mead & White and to oversee the building of depots, terminals, and hotels for the Northern Pacific Railroad. Within two years, the office collapsed and Gilbert formed a partnership with James Knox Taylor in St. Paul that lasted until 1892. Gilbert produced churches and houses in Minnesota and was a recognized architect when he won a competition to design the Minnesota State Capitol in 1895.

In 1899, Gilbert returned to New York City and received a number of significant commissions. He won a competition to design the United States Custom House (1901-1907) and designed the 24 storied building at 90 West Street (1905-1907) in Manhattan. From 1911-1913, Gilbert worked on the Woolworth Building. At 55 stories tall, it was the tallest building in the world from 1913 to 1930 and became one of Gilbert's most famous designs. Other buildings in New York designed by Gilbert include the New York Life Insurance Company Building (1925-1928) and the US Courthouse (1936), which was completed after his death. Gilbert also completed designs for the George Washington Memorial Bridge (1927-1931) that proved to be too expensive and were never used.

Gilbert also became known for his work on the Art Building in the Louisiana Purchase Exposition in 1904 which eventually became the St. Louis Art Museum. He also designed the St. Louis Public Library (1907-1912) and the Detroit Public Library (1913-1921). His work in Washington D.C. included the US Treasury Annex (1918-1919), the US Chamber of Commerce (1924-1925), and the US Supreme Court Building (1933-1935).

Gilbert was active in art and architectural organizations. He was appointed by President Theodore Roosevelt as chairman of the Council of Fine Arts. He was made a member of the Commission of Fine Arts by President Taft and reappointed to the post by President Woodrow Wilson. He was a long time member of the American Institute of Architects and served as its president from 1908-1909. In 1919 he resigned his membership from the AIA after disputes with the leadership of the organization. He was also a long time member of the National Academy of Design and served as its president from 1926-1932. He also served as a member of the National Institute of Arts and Letters.

Gilbert was recognized in America and abroad for his architectural work. He received honorary degrees from the University of Michigan, Oberlin College, and Middlebury College and was awarded the Society of Art and Sciences Gold Medal Award in 1930. In Europe, he was made an honorary member of the Agricultural Society of the University of Liverpool and an honorary foreign member of the Royal Academy of Arts. He was also decorated with the French Legion of Honor.

In 1887, Gilbert married Julia Tappan Finch, the daughter of a wealthy attorney from Milwaukee. Together they had three children: Cass Gilbert Jr., Emily Finch, and Julia Swift who became the wife of Charles Morgan Post. The family owned many properties including places in Manhattan and Connecticut. Gilbert was active in various social clubs including the Century Club and the Union Club. Gilbert died on vacation in Brockenhurst, England in 1934 at the age of 75. Cass Gilbert Jr. worked as an architect in his father's office and finished many of the office's projects after his death.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Cass Gilbert Collection spans the period from 1883-1952 (bulk 1900-1934) and contains professional and personal papers relating to the architect Cass Gilbert. This finding aid does not include information on the architectural drawings of Cass Gilbert. Most of this collection consists of files related to his numerous architectural projects. These files contain materials related to projects that he completed as well as projects that he worked on but did not complete. The collection also documents his extensive work in art and architectural associations. His personal papers mainly relate to personal business and some family letters are included. The arrangement attempts to adhere to Gilbert's filing system as closely as possible. See the Print Room at the New-York Historical Society for a detailed box and folder listing for the collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is divided into nine series:

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at the Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections
relatedmaterial.p: The Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections at the New-York Historical Society also holds the architectural drawings of many of Cass Gilbert's projects.

Photographs of many Cass Gilbert projects can be found in the Geographic File, PR20. A photograph of the dinner thrown by F.W. Woolworth in Cass Gilbert's honor can be found in the Portrait File, PR52, under Groups, Commercial, in Large Format. There is also a photograph of Cass Gilbert and his family in the Portrait File, PR 52, under "G" in Medium Format.

did.unittitle: Series I. Project Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes material related to Cass Gilbert's architectural projects. Most of the projects are buildings built by Gilbert. However the files also include information on projects he competed for but did not receive or are documents regarding a particular subject or a business. This series represents the bulk of the collection.

did.unittitle: Subseries I: Foldered Material

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains the box and foldered material regarding Cass Gilbert projects. The material has been filed alphabetically by project and then by the project number assigned by Gilbert's office. Gilbert also designated material within the project files by type. Thus, the project files are also divided by type of material. The types of material include Preliminary Correspondence, Correspondence, Memoranda/Notes, Specifications, Bid Documents, Proposals, Reports, Contracts/Agreements, Financial Statements (includes Requisitions), Change Orders, Drawings, Photographs, etc.

Many of these volumes are fragile and access is dependent upon the judgment of the print room staff.

Series II. Office Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes all administrative files relating to Gilbert's professional career and the running of his office. This includes information on his employees, the products and services used by the office, and the different office spaces inhabited by the architecture firm. The office files also document Gilbert's outside professional work such as serving as a judge for architecture competitions, advising on city planning, and his opposition to a plan to build a power plant in Washington D.C. Most of the files are designated #103.

did.unittitle: Subseries I: Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The office correspondence is mostly incoming and any significant amounts of outgoing copies are filed separately. The letters are filed by date and then by correspondent. The general office correspondence consists of letters regarding potential projects, businesses promoting their products, and orders for supplies. Correspondence regarding workers consists of letters of introduction, men's letters asking for work, and a set of letters from office employees who want recommendations to serve in World War I. The correspondence also includes professional matters such as asking Cass Gilbert to speak at events or to judge architecture competitions. This subseries includes letters from Cass Gilbert Jr. if they relate to the business. Personal letters from Cass Gilbert, Jr. can be found in Series IV.

Series III. Professional Organizations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes documents relating to Cass Gilbert's involvement in art and architectural organizations. Files relating to his participation in other organizations or causes are located within his personal files. The organizations most heavily represented are the American Institute of Architects, the Commission of Fine Arts, and the National Academy of Design.

did.unittitle: Subseries I. Foldered Material:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Most of the subseries consists of correspondence but memoranda, reports and brochures are also included. The files regarding the American Institute of Architects include materials on the national organization as well as the state and local chapters. The files also include correspondence regarding his resignation from the AIA.

Series IV. Personal Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes Gilbert's files that do not reflect his architectural work or professional life. The material includes letters among his friends and family as well as important papers from his personal life.

did.unittitle: Subseries I: Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of incoming letters to Cass Gilbert. The correspondence includes personal letters from family, friends, and colleagues relating to matters such as his insurance, the purchase and upkeep of his properties, automobile maintenance, and family finances. Many of the letters also document his donations to organizations such as anti-prohibition groups and patriotic organizations in World War I. Letters from his family include letters from his wife Julia Finch Gilbert, letters from his brother Samuel relating to Gilbert's insurance policies, and letters from his brother Charles related to property. Letters from other family members are included. Correspondence from colleagues includes letters from Edwin Blashfield, Alexander Calder, Daniel Chester French, F.H. Olmstead, Sir Aston Webb, etc. Some letters to Cass Gilbert from 1918-1919 relate to Cass Gilbert Jr.'s service in WWI. Incoming correspondence to other family members is also included. These include many sympathy letters to the Gilbert family after the death of Cass in 1934.

Subseries III: Financial Documents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The financial documents include bills and receipts as well as tax and estate papers of the Gilbert family.

did.unittitle: Bills and Receipts
Estate Papers
Tax Assessments
Subseries IV: Invitations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains invitations to events from friends and organizations. Included are invitations to the White House by Presidents Theodore Roosevelt and Herbert Hoover. A small amount of invitations by Cass Gilbert are also included.

did.unittitle: Invitations to Cass Gilbert (including White House Invitations)
Invitations by Cass Gilbert and Responses Received
Subseries V: Speeches and Writings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of speeches given by Cass Gilbert, usually his acceptance speeches of awards and honors. It also includes poems and prefaces to books by Cass Gilbert and other unidentified writers.

did.unittitle: Speeches
Speeches by Other Authors
Prefaces to Books
Poems by Cass Gilbert and Others
Subseries VI: Property Information

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The property information includes agreements, specifications, contractor information, and drawings for property owned by Cass Gilbert and the Gilbert family.

did.unittitle: #1-#5 East 94th Street
71 Floral Street
Huntington, Long Island
James House
Shepaug Farm
Subseries VII: Brochures

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes brochures saved by Cass Gilbert regarding water pumps, anti-prohibition organizations, and other groups.

did.unittitle: Brochures- Water Pumps, Anti-Prohibition Organizations, Proposed Public Works Department, etc.
Subseries VIII: Clippings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The clippings include articles regarding politics and architecture. A folder of obituaries for Cass Gilbert is also included.

did.unittitle: Clippings related to World War I and Cass Gilbert's Career and His Death
Subseries IX: Photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The small amount of personal photographs in this subseries consist of pictures of family, colleagues, and property.

did.unittitle: Photographs- Family and Colleagues
Subseries X: Illustrations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes drawings of architecture including the Parthenon and the Acropolis.

did.unittitle: Illustrations by Cass Gilbert and Others
Subseries XI. Publications

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains issues of publications regarding Gilbert's personal interests.

did.unittitle: Publications saved by Cass Gilbert
Subseries XII: Other

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains folders of personal materials that do not fit in with the above subseries. It includes passports of Cass Gilbert, papers regarding family genealogy, and his written memories of important events.

did.unittitle: Other Family Papers
Subseries XIII: Bound Volumes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains letterbooks of personal outgoing correspondence. Topics include expenses, residences, his work on World War I committees, etc. One book contains letters regarding Cass Gilbert, Jr's work with the American Society of the French Legion of Honor. Many of these volumes are fragile and access is dependent upon the judgment of the print room staff.

did.unittitle: Letterbooks
Letterbook, American Society of the French Legion of Honor (Cass Gilbert, Jr.)
Series V. Lantern Slides

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The lantern slides include glass slides of some of Cass Gilbert's projects as well as studies of other buildings around the world. The slides are divided into two subseries that reflect Gilbert's numbering of the slides. It appears that the two groups of slides were used for two separate purposes.

did.unittitle: Subseries I: Woolworth Building

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries of lantern slides depicts only the Woolworth Building. The images include exteriors and interiors as well as depictions of construction and the finished building. Most of these images are also represented in the photographs in the Woolworth Building section of the Project Files series.

did.unittitle: Lantern Slides of the Woolworth Building
Subseries II: National and International Cites

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries of lantern slides depicts all types of architecture from all over the world including bridges, fountains, parks, museums, and villas. Although a few of Gilbert's projects are represented in this subseries (St. Louis Art Museum, Belle Isle Bridge) most of the slides are not of his work. The slides represent architecture in the United States as well as in France, Italy, England, Holland, Spain, Japan, and Germany.
